item.title: Iranians Brace for War as Trump Considers Targeted Strikes
item.content:encoded: Stores are well stocked, and there have been no reports of shortages of food and other essentials, but many Iranians are in limbo as they wait to see whether U.S. forces will attack.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariffs Are Illegal Too
item.content:encoded: Just another attempt to ignore the law and dare the courts to step in.

item.title: Racing to Catch up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.content:encoded: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.

item.title: Racing to Catch up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.content:encoded: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.

item.title: A Blizzard With Record Snowfall for Parts of the Northeast
item.content:encoded: At the storm’s peak, well over half a million homes and businesses in the Northeast were without power.

item.title: How Jeffrey Epstein Ingratiated Himself With Top Microsoft Executives
item.content:encoded: For more than two decades, the convicted sex offender developed a network at the tech giant, making him privy to succession discussions and other business.

item.title: State of the Union May Be a Trial for ‘Barely Invited’ Justices
item.content:encoded: If tradition holds, members of the Supreme Court will attend Trump’s annual speech, just days after ruling against the legality of his tariffs.

item.title: Robert Carradine, Actor Who Played the Father in ‘Lizzie McGuire,’ Dies at 71
item.content:encoded: A member of a renowned acting dynasty, he also earned fame for his role in “Revenge of the Nerds.” His family said he struggled with bipolar disorder.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.content:encoded: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.content:encoded: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.content:encoded: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.content:encoded: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teens think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”

item.title: Inside the Big Tech Lobbying Machine Aiming to Halt Social Media Bans
item.content:encoded: Tech giants, including Meta and Alphabet, are spending lavishly on splashy billboard ads, courting on-the-fence politicians and bulking up their ranks of lobbyists.

item.title: Russia Moves Closer to Banning Telegram App, Saying It Foments Terrorism
item.content:encoded: News of an investigation into Pavel Durov, the app’s billionaire founder, deepened a crackdown on what remains of the free Russian internet.

item.title: Trump’s Justice Department Sues New Jersey Governor Over ICE Enforcement
item.content:encoded: The lawsuit is the latest federal challenge to policies enacted in Democrat-led states. Similar suits have targeted laws in New York, Minnesota and California.

item.title: Mexico Is Caught Between Trump and the Cartels
item.content:encoded: President Trump has demanded President Claudia Sheinbaum confront the cartels. The killing of “El Mencho” suggests it might be working — but could come at a cost.

item.title: Storm Leads to a First for The Boston Globe: A Day Without a Paper
item.content:encoded: The company said the blizzard had made it too treacherous for workers to make it to the printing press on Monday.

item.title: After Saks Bankruptcy, Richard Baker Says He Saved Luxury Department Stores
item.content:encoded: Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Go Into Effect at 10 Percent, Not 15
item.content:encoded: The change surprised executives and foreign leaders, who had been expecting the 15 percent rate the president announced on Saturday.

item.title: Mandelson’s Arrest Adds to Scandal That Has Rattled Starmer and Labour Party
item.content:encoded: The arrest of the British former envoy to Washington, long a key figure in the Labour Party, deepened a scandal that has led to calls for Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s resignation.

item.title: What to Know in NYC After Blizzard: School Closures, Transportation and More
item.content:encoded: Public schools and Broadway theaters will be open, but transit and flight disruptions could linger.

item.title: Gustavo Dudamel’s Long Goodbye to L.A., and Long Hello to New York
item.content:encoded: As the conductor prepares to leave the Los Angeles Philharmonic for the New York Philharmonic, he says, “I am in two waters.”

item.title: Is It Safe to Travel to Mexico Right Now, Given the Cartel Violence?
item.content:encoded: A wave of unrest after the killing of a cartel leader has rattled tourists at popular destinations in Mexico, prompting travelers to reconsider their plans. Here’s what to know.

item.title: Corporate America’s Growing Quest for Tariff Refunds
item.content:encoded: Thousands of companies are expected to follow FedEx’ in suing the government to recoup levy payments, after the Supreme Court overturned the tariffs.

item.title: New York City’s Homeless Population Endures Another Dangerous Storm
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani said on Monday that his administration had taken lessons from the city’s last storm, when at least 20 people died after exposure to the cold.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.content:encoded: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.content:encoded: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.

item.title: Trump Is Turning the F.C.C. and F.T.C. Against Free Expression
item.content:encoded: Trump appointees have transformed the F.T.C. and F.C.C. into instruments of ideological enforcement.

item.title: Ahead of State of the Union, Cracks Appear in Trump Coalition
item.content:encoded: As the president prepares to speak to the nation, Northeastern Pennsylvania is showing discontent on the edges of the Trump coalition and an energized Democratic opposition.

item.title: Mamdani’s Vanquished Foes Are Plotting a Comeback, if Not Revenge
item.content:encoded: Many of New York City’s wealthy and well-connected power players find themselves in an unfamiliar place: the wilderness.

item.title: Your Tariff Questions
item.content:encoded: We’re addressing some of your concerns about President Trump’s tariff regime.

item.title: China Amps Up Pressure on Japan With Restrictions on Exports
item.content:encoded: Beijing placed the restrictions on 20 Japanese entities with ties to the defense industry, the latest ratcheting up of its monthslong feud with Tokyo.

item.title: ICE Whistle-Blower Says Training Is ‘Broken,’ and OpenAI Faces Questions About Mass Shooter
item.content:encoded: Plus, how Mexico tracked its most-wanted cartel leader.

item.title: Intel Strikes Deal With a Chip Start-Up Its C.E.O. Invested In
item.content:encoded: A technical partnership embraces SambaNova Systems, which Intel’s chief, Lip-Bu Tan, helps lead as an investor and chairman.

item.title: How Russia Put Its Future at Risk by Remaking Its Economy for War
item.content:encoded: About half of the country’s federal budget goes toward the fight in Ukraine, money that does little to support its long-term development.

item.title: Trump State of the Union Speech 2026: How to Watch, Time and Attendees
item.content:encoded: President Trump will speak at 9 p.m. Eastern time to a joint session of Congress. The New York Times will carry the address live.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.content:encoded: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.content:encoded: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.

item.title: In Blow to Mamdani, Left-Leaning Group Breaks With Mayor Over U.S. House Race
item.content:encoded: Mayor Zohran Mamdani of New York had lobbied for his preferred candidate, Claire Valdez. But the party backed Antonio Reynoso, the Brooklyn borough president.

item.title: Late Night Sums Up Trump’s Tariff Tiff with the Supreme Court
item.content:encoded: “Wow, a court composed mostly of his own party’s appointees has struck down the constitutionality of Trump’s go-it-alone tariff regime,” Jon Stewart said. “That’s bound to cause him some introspection.”

item.title: Mexican Forces Say They Tracked El Mencho to Cabin by Following His Lover
item.content:encoded: Top security officials revealed details of the operation that led to the death of Mexico’s most wanted drug cartel leader.

item.title: These Ukrainians Don’t Want to Be Traded to Russia for Peace
item.content:encoded: Four years into the war, a major sticking point in talks is control of the eastern Donetsk region. Residents could face an agonizing choice if Ukraine gives up the territory.

item.title: What Brontë Country Tells Us About Britain Today
item.content:encoded: West Yorkshire, where the original “Wuthering Heights” was written, offers a window into the forces that are disrupting British politics.

item.title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
item.content:encoded: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.

item.title: Trump Says General Caine Sees Easy Victory if U.S. Attacks Iran
item.content:encoded: The remarks differ from what Gen. Dan Caine, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is said to have told the president in high-level White House meetings.

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.content:encoded: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.

item.title: What Travelers Need to Know About the Blizzard
item.content:encoded: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and widespread cancellations across much of the Northeast. We’ve got advice for stranded travelers.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.content:encoded: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.content:encoded: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Are Canceled as Storm Slams Northeast Airports
item.content:encoded: Airlines suspended operations at some major airports and expect to restart some flights on Monday and more on Tuesday.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.content:encoded: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.content:encoded: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.

item.title: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast
item.content:encoded: The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.content:encoded: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.content:encoded: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
item.content:encoded: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.content:encoded: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.

item.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
item.content:encoded: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.

item.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
item.content:encoded: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is Trending in Schools. Here’s Why.
item.content:encoded: Artificial intelligence companies are urging teachers to prepare students for an “A.I.-driven future.” What that means varies from school to school.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.content:encoded: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.content:encoded: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.content:encoded: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.

item.title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
item.content:encoded: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: For India, Buying Russian Oil Just Got More Complicated
item.content:encoded: India’s prime minister acceded to many of President Trump’s demands under pressure of heavy tariffs. It would be awkward to reject them now.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.content:encoded: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.content:encoded: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.content:encoded: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.content:encoded: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.

item.title: Trump Doubles Down on Closing Tax Loophole on Cheap Imports
item.content:encoded: The exemption was shut down last year by President Trump based, in part, on the same legal grounds as the tariffs that were invalidated by the Supreme Court.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Raise Global Tariff to 15 Percent
item.content:encoded: The move signaled that the president would press ahead with steep global import taxes despite the legal setback from the Supreme Court.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.content:encoded: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.content:encoded: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it

item.title: Businesses Celebrate Tariff Relief, And Brace for New Uncertainty
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling against many of President Trump’s tariffs cheered executives who set to work seeking refunds on their duties.

item.title: Six Questions on the Future of Trump’s Tariffs
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court’s ruling on the president’s tariffs has jolted Washington and the business world. Here’s what to watch next.

item.title: With Tariff Changes, Consumers May Be Stuck in a Waiting Game
item.content:encoded: Some companies could decide to temper price increases, but the effect would take time to materialize.

item.title: ‘Murky Waters’ for Global Businesses After Trump’s Tariff Loss
item.content:encoded: Even after the Supreme Court invalidated many of the president’s levies, foreign leaders and executives assume that U.S. tariffs are here to stay, in one form or another.

item.title: He Researched Dishonesty. He Got Friendly With Jeffrey Epstein.
item.content:encoded: Dan Ariely, a behavioral scientist at Duke, sought out the convicted sex offender for his research. Their yearslong correspondence suggests it wasn’t all business.

item.title: Fred Segal Has a New Owner. This Time It’s Aritzia.
item.content:encoded: The storied Los Angeles retailer, once recognized as an arbiter of West Coast style, has been acquired by the mass-market brand Aritzia.

item.title: Ask The Morning: The Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.content:encoded: The justices struck down a central piece of President Trump’s agenda. What does that mean?

item.title: Supreme Court Tariff Ruling to Spur Chaotic Refund Process
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration says it could take years and additional litigation for importers to get their money back.
